CHAPTER 39: COMMAND AND CONTROL

Date: November 16, 1432 - Late Afternoon
Location: Hall of Ambassadors, Alhambra Palace, Granada

The light slanting through the ornate windows had shifted toward amber when Álvaro de Luna approached the throne where you sat.

"Your Majesty, the commanders are assembling in the Court of the Lions as you ordered. We should begin soon—there are decisions that cannot wait until morning."

He glanced toward the windows overlooking the city below. "Granada is ours by surrender, but we do not yet hold it. Eight thousand disarmed soldiers wondering what happens next. Fifty thousand civilians uncertain whether their world ends tonight or tomorrow. An army of twenty thousand men who've been fighting for eighteen months and don't know if they're staying or going home."

The Infantes entered together—Juan moving with his characteristic measured grace, Enrique's hand resting habitually on where his sword would be if he still wore one. Behind them came the Masters of the three Military Orders, their distinctive crosses catching the light. Don Fadrique Enríquez. Senior commanders whose names you'd learned over months of campaign. Perhaps twenty men in total, the core leadership of the crusade that had just conquered the last Muslim kingdom in Iberia.

Fray Hernando arrived last, still wearing his simple brown robe despite the grandeur surrounding him. The white crusade banner remained planted outside in the courtyard where he'd carried it through Granada's streets this morning.

"The council chamber is ready, Your Majesty," Álvaro said quietly. "Shall we proceed?"

The Court of the Lions waited—the famous fountain still flowing, its twelve marble lions supporting the basin as they had for a century. The surrounding colonnade provided a setting both open to the November air and sheltered, with enough space for your commanders to gather around the fountain itself.

As you rose from the throne of Granada and walked toward the council, what occupied your thoughts most?

Álvaro considered the question as the council assembled around the fountain in the Court of the Lions. The Masters of the Military Orders exchanged glances, and Infante Juan—Brother Juan now—leaned forward with interest.

"A wise choice, Your Majesty," Álvaro said. "Major nobles would bring factional complications and ambitions. A minor noble with proven capability who owes his elevation entirely to Your Majesty's favor..." He nodded approvingly.

The Master of Santiago spoke first: "Don Rodrigo de Perea. He's been with the eastern army since the beginning—presented the intelligence assessments at the war council before Alhama. Minor house from León, no great wealth or connections, but sharp mind and steady hand. The scouts respect him."

"Mid-thirties," Infante Enrique added. "Fought at Alcalá, commanded reconnaissance during the march east. Not flashy, but competent."

Don Fadrique Enríquez offered another name: "Don García López de Padilla. Distant cousin to the Master of Calatrava but from a minor branch—no significant inheritance. He's been in every major engagement. The men know him, which matters when establishing authority in a conquered city."

Álvaro tapped his fingers thoughtfully on the fountain's edge. "Both solid choices. Rodrigo is more administrative—good for organizing the practical matters of governance. García is more of a soldier—better if you anticipate potential unrest requiring firm military hand."

He paused, then added: "There's also Don Pedro de Acuña. Younger—perhaps twenty-eight—but he managed the logistics for the southern valley campaign under Infante Juan. Quartermaster work mostly, but he kept three thousand men supplied through mountain terrain for months. That's the kind of practical capability a governor needs."

The Master of Calatrava nodded: "Acuña has that quiet efficiency. No one notices him until you realize everything is somehow working."

Álvaro looked at you directly: "Any of the three could do it, Your Majesty. The question is what quality you value most for this particular challenge—intelligence and reconnaissance experience, military presence and battlefield authority, or administrative competence and logistics?"

The commanders waited for your assessment.

I believe we have the vizier present as well. You would honour us if you would stay as advisor to prevent misunderstandings. Would you stay for a while?

The Master of Santiago nodded with evident approval. "García it is. A soldier's presence will matter in these first weeks. The garrison may be disarmed, but they're watching to see if we keep our word or turn to the sword."

"I'll send for him immediately," Álvaro said, gesturing to a waiting aide. "Don García López de Padilla, temporary Governor of Granada, serving at Your Majesty's pleasure until proper administration established."

Don Fadrique added quietly: "He's not cruel, Your Majesty. Firm, but fair. Fought at Alcalá and saw how you handled the conversions—he'll understand the approach you want."

Infante Juan spoke up: "The vizier is still in the palace, awaiting word on the Sultan's departure arrangements. Shall I have him brought to the council?"

At your confirmation, one of the Castilian guards was dispatched. Minutes later, Vizier Ahmad ibn Khalil entered the Court of the Lions, moving slowly among the Christian commanders. His court robes seemed somehow diminished in this setting, surrounded by men in armor and crusader crosses. He bowed deeply.

"Your Majesty commands my presence?"

When you extended your request—that he remain as advisor to prevent misunderstandings during the transition—the elderly diplomat's face showed surprise, then something that might have been relief.

"Your Majesty would... retain me? After the surrender?" He glanced around at the assembled commanders, perhaps expecting objection. "I have served Sultan Yusuf for twenty-three years. I administered Granada's governance, its finances, its—"

He stopped himself, choosing words carefully: "Forgive me. I served the former Sultan. Granada is now yours by right of conquest and lawful surrender. If Your Majesty believes this old servant can be of use preventing chaos or bloodshed during the transition, then... yes. I would be honored to remain as advisor. My knowledge of the city's administration, the grain distribution networks, the civil structures—these things do not change with the banners on the walls."

The vizier's voice grew steadier: "And perhaps... perhaps I can help Don García understand our people. Help him see that they are not enemies to be subdued, but subjects to be governed. If that is indeed Your Majesty's intent?"

The question hung in the air—a test, perhaps, of whether your mercy extended beyond the formal ceremony.

Álvaro immediately began organizing the details: "Mixed delegations—yes, that will reduce the chance of violence. Each party should have a Muslim official who can read the surrender document in Arabic, and a Christian officer to represent Your Majesty's authority. Perhaps six delegations total?"

The vizier interjected: "If I may suggest, Your Majesty—the qadis, the Islamic judges in the outlying districts, are respected figures. If they accompany your messengers and confirm that the Sultan surrendered lawfully and with compensation, it will carry great weight. The people will accept it as legitimate rather than mere conquest."

"Almería is the largest remaining stronghold," Martín added, consulting mental maps. "Perhaps eight hundred to a thousand garrison. Then scattered watchtowers in the southern valleys, a few minor fortresses. None can hold alone now that Granada city has fallen."

Infante Enrique nodded: "If they hear the Sultan surrendered with honor and compensation, with Muslim officials confirming it, most will lay down arms. No point dying for a kingdom that no longer exists."

When you raised the question of the surrendered garrison—offering conversion and employment—the Master of Santiago leaned forward with interest.

"Practical," he said approvingly. "Eight thousand disarmed men. Some will want to leave, but others?" He glanced at the vizier. "Some will have families here, roots, nowhere else to go. If conversion offers them continued livelihood..."

The vizier spoke carefully: "Many of the garrison are Granada-born. Their families are in the city. The choice between exile and conversion, when conversion offers continued purpose and income..." He paused. "Some will see it as betrayal. Others as survival and practicality. But the offer itself shows mercy rather than simply casting them out penniless."

Then you asked about disbanding the noble levies.

Álvaro's face showed the relief of a man who'd been waiting for this question. "Your Majesty, yes—most of them, certainly. The nobles have been in field since April of last year. Eighteen months. Their estates need them, their families need them, and frankly the treasury needs to stop paying their provisions."

He held up a hand, forestalling complete celebration: "But not quite yet. Not until those outlying fortresses formally surrender. If Almería's garrison decides to be difficult, we'd need to demonstrate we still have overwhelming force. Give the delegations two weeks to complete their circuit—by early December we'll know if anyone intends to resist."

The Master of Calatrava added: "The Military Orders stay, obviously. Granada will need permanent garrison, and that's precisely what we're for. Between Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara, we can maintain perhaps fifteen hundred knights and men-at-arms here indefinitely."

"Plus converted garrison troops," the Master of Santiago noted, "and whatever crown forces Your Majesty assigns. We can hold Granada with that."

Álvaro continued: "So my recommendation: Announce now that levies will be disbanded in two weeks, pending confirmation all territories have surrendered. That gives the nobles certainty, prevents grumbling, and keeps them available if needed. By December first, assuming no resistance, they march home with Your Majesty's thanks and appropriate compensation."

He smiled slightly: "They'll be thrilled, Your Majesty. Home for Christmas after conquering Granada. That's a story they'll tell their grandchildren."

Don Fadrique Enríquez spoke up: "What of your crusaders, Your Majesty? Their oaths are fulfilled. Do they stay or disperse?"

"Should take most of the morning, assuming perhaps twelve to fifteen new titles. Then Your Majesty rides for Toledo?"

He exchanged looks with the Infantes. "That's... nine days' hard riding, Your Majesty. Assuming good weather and no delays. You'll reach Toledo by November 25th."

Infante Juan spoke carefully: "Your Majesty has been in field since May of last year. Eighteen months. The Queen has been waiting in Toledo since..." He calculated. "Since you marched east in March. Eight months."

The vizier raised a hand tentatively. "Your Majesty, a practical matter—the former Sultan's departure. He is preparing his household, but the actual logistics of escort, safe conduct to the border, the payment of the ten thousand florins... these details require arrangement."

Álvaro nodded. "I can manage that in your absence, but we should clarify: Does he leave immediately, or is there a timeline?"

The Master of Calatrava added another concern: "And command structure while Your Majesty returns to Toledo? Who holds supreme authority in Granada? Governor García reports to...?"

Don Fadrique offered: "The six delegations to outlying fortresses—they should depart immediately, yes? Before the noble levies disperse, so the fortresses see we still have overwhelming force available if needed?"
